metadata.purpose: Financial transaction network fraud detection datasets
metadata.validation_status: URLs and access methods verified as of 2025-12-24

access_method.method_1: Kaggle API: kaggle datasets download -d ellipticco/elliptic-data-set
access_method.authentication_required: Kaggle API token (kaggle.json) required for API access

feature_breakdown.description: Local features are transaction-specific. Aggregate features represent 1-hop backward/forward neighbor statistics (max, min, std, correlation)

feature_types: 72 aggregate features (neighbor statistics: max, min, std, correlation)
features.anonymization: All features anonymized for privacy; original feature names not disclosed

illicit.description: Transactions associated with illicit activities (scams, ransomware, etc.)

licit.description: Legitimate transactions from verified exchanges, services

labels.fraud_rate_overall: 2.0% of all transactions labeled as fraudulent

temporal_span.temporal_structure: 49 weakly connected components, one per time step

graph_structure.edge_direction: Represents Bitcoin flow from one transaction to another

known_limitations.limitation_1: Only ~0.1% of total Bitcoin transactions (very small subsample)
known_limitations.limitation_2: Feature anonymization prevents domain-specific feature engineering
known_limitations.limitation_4: Class imbalance: only 2% labeled as illicit overall
known_limitations.limitation_5: Time-step granularity (~2 weeks) may miss short-term patterns
known_limitations.limitation_6: No ground truth for 'unknown' class - potential label noise
known_limitations.limitation_7: Diameter and clustering coefficient not reported
known_limitations.limitation_8: Relatively low connectivity (avg degree 1.15) limits GNN neighborhood aggregation

license.usage_restrictions: Review Kaggle dataset page for current license terms
license.attribution_required: Yes - cite original paper and dataset
license.citation: Weber, M., et al. (2019). Anti-Money Laundering in Bitcoin: Experimenting with Graph Convolutional Networks for Financial Forensics. KDD Workshop on Anomaly Detection in Finance.

validation_notes.data_quality: High quality, professionally curated by Elliptic Co.
validation_notes.anomalies: Class imbalance is primary data challenge
validation_notes.recommended_splits: Temporal split recommended (earlier time steps for train, later for test)

research_impact.popularity: De facto standard for Bitcoin fraud detection research

source.provider: Vesta Corporation & IEEE Computational Intelligence Society

access_method.method_1: Kaggle Competition Data: kaggle competitions download -c ieee-fraud-detection
access_method.method_2: Direct download from Kaggle competition data page
access_method.authentication_required: Kaggle account + accept competition rules required

files: test_identity.csv - Identity information for test set
file_structure.note: Not all transactions have corresponding identity information

transaction_features.ProductCD: Product code (W, C, R, H, S)

card_features.card1_to_card6: Card type, category, issuing bank, country, etc.

vesta_features.V1_to_V339: Vesta engineered features (ranking, counting, entity relations)

features.missing_values: 194 columns contain at least one missing value
features.anonymization: Many features anonymized (V1-V339, C1-C14, D1-D15, etc.)

temporal_span.note: Exact date range not disclosed for privacy

graph_construction_potential.construction_method: User-defined (dataset does not provide pre-built graph)
graph_construction_potential.note: Researchers must construct graph from tabular data

known_limitations.limitation_1: Extensive missing values (194/434 columns have missing data)
known_limitations.limitation_3: No pre-built graph structure (tabular data only)
known_limitations.limitation_5: Vesta features proprietary - cannot replicate on other data
known_limitations.limitation_7: Identity information only available for subset of transactions
known_limitations.limitation_8: Requires significant feature engineering and missing value imputation
known_limitations.limitation_9: Dataset reflects Vesta's specific e-commerce context (may not generalize)

license.usage_restrictions: Must accept competition rules to access data
license.attribution_required: Yes - acknowledge IEEE-CIS and Vesta Corporation

validation_notes.data_quality: High quality, real-world e-commerce data from Vesta
validation_notes.anomalies: Some categorical features have very high cardinality
validation_notes.preprocessing_required: Extensive - missing value imputation, feature engineering, scaling
validation_notes.recommended_approach: Ensemble methods, gradient boosting (XGBoost, LightGBM), feature selection

research_impact.popularity: One of largest fraud detection competitions
research_impact.benchmark_status: Standard benchmark for tabular fraud detection

source.provider: Machine Learning Group - Université Libre de Bruxelles (MLG-ULB)
source.original_paper: Dal Pozzolo et al. - Calibrating Probability with Undersampling for Unbalanced Classification

access_method.method_1: Kaggle API: kaggle datasets download -d mlg-ulb/creditcardfraud
access_method.authentication_required: Kaggle API token (kaggle.json) for API access

files: creditcard.csv - 284,807 rows x 31 columns (30 features + 1 label)

pca_features.note: Original feature names not disclosed due to confidentiality

Time.description: Seconds elapsed between each transaction and first transaction

temporal_span.note: Short temporal span limits long-term pattern analysis

possible_approaches: Temporal proximity edges (transactions close in time)
Feature similarity edges (k-NN graph based on V1-V28)
graph_construction_potential.note: Graph construction would be artificial - not recommended

graph_structure.average_degree: Not applicable (tabular data, no natural graph)

known_limitations.limitation_2: PCA transformation removes interpretability and domain knowledge
known_limitations.limitation_3: Cannot perform feature engineering on original features
known_limitations.limitation_4: Only 48-hour window - no long-term temporal patterns
known_limitations.limitation_9: 2013 data - fraud patterns may have evolved
known_limitations.limitation_10: No information about fraud types or attack vectors

license.usage_restrictions: Free to use for research and education
license.citation: Dal Pozzolo, A., et al. (2015). Calibrating Probability with Undersampling for Unbalanced Classification. IEEE Symposium Series on Computational Intelligence.

validation_notes.data_quality: High quality, well-curated, no missing values
validation_notes.anomalies: Extreme class imbalance is primary challenge
validation_notes.recommended_metrics: Precision-Recall AUC, F1-score, not accuracy (due to imbalance)
validation_notes.evaluation_strategy: Stratified k-fold cross-validation or temporal split

research_impact.status: De facto standard benchmark for imbalanced classification
research_impact.popularity: Most popular fraud detection dataset on Kaggle
research_impact.community: Extensive tutorials, kernels, and discussions available

best_for_graph_learning.reason: Native graph structure, 203K nodes, 234K edges, temporal dynamics

best_for_feature_richness.reason: 434 features including engineered Vesta features, device/browser info

best_for_imbalanced_learning.reason: Extreme imbalance (0.172%), clean data, standard benchmark

recommendations.primary_recommendation: Use Elliptic Bitcoin Dataset for graph-based fraud detection research
rationale: Native graph structure (DAG) with 203K nodes and 234K edges
Temporal dynamics across 49 time steps (~23 months)
Realistic fraud rate (~2% labeled as illicit)
Supports both supervised and semi-supervised learning
Active research community and extensive benchmarks
recommendations.secondary_recommendation: Use IEEE-CIS for feature-rich tabular fraud detection
recommendations.tertiary_recommendation: Use ULB dataset for imbalanced learning baselines

multi_dataset_strategy.approach: Evaluate on all three datasets for comprehensive assessment
multi_dataset_strategy.challenge: Different data modalities require different model architectures

synthetic_data_justification.reason: Three high-quality real-world datasets available covering different aspects
when_synthetic_might_help: If graph diameter/clustering properties need specific values (not reported for Elliptic)
If controlled fraud network patterns needed (e.g., fraud rings with known structure)
If privacy regulations prevent use of real data
For ablation studies isolating specific graph properties

synthetic_generation_approach.method: Stochastic Block Model (SBM) with fraud communities

parameters.community_structure: Fraud rings with higher intra-community connectivity
parameters.features: Generate using mixture models or copy Elliptic distribution

synthetic_generation_approach.validation: Compare graph statistics (degree distribution, clustering, etc.) to real data

next_steps.step_1: Download Elliptic dataset using Kaggle API
next_steps.step_2: Perform exploratory data analysis (EDA) and compute graph statistics
next_steps.step_3: Validate data quality (check for missing values, outliers, etc.)
next_steps.step_4: Compute missing graph properties (diameter, clustering coefficient)
